title: 108_s1451
content: The Act is titled the "Runaway, Homeless, and Missing Children Protection Act." It amends the findings section of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act. The Congress finds that youth who are homeless or run away from home without parental permission are at risk of serious health and behavioral problems. They lack resources for care and may live on the streets, creating law enforcement issues. These young people urgently need temporary shelter and linguistically appropriate services. The Federal Government has a responsibility to address this interstate problem. The Federal Government must develop a national reporting system and provide care services for runaway and homeless youth to help them transition to adulthood successfully. Improved coordination between Federal programs is necessary to address the needs of these vulnerable youth. Improved coordination and collaboration between Federal programs serving runaway and homeless youth are necessary for developing a long-term strategy to meet their needs. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to change the heading for part A to "Basic Center" and include testing for sexually transmitted diseases at the request of youth. An obsolete provision related to certain allotments is repealed. SEC. 104 of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act repeals an obsolete provision related to certain allotments. SEC. 105 amends eligibility provisions by replacing "juveniles" with "youth." SEC. 106 recognizes state law relating to capacity limitations on eligible runaway and homeless youth centers. SEC. 106 recognizes state law regarding capacity limits for eligible runaway and homeless youth centers. SEC. 107 addresses maternity group homes. SEC. 107 addresses maternity group homes, amending the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to include maternity group homes as transitional living arrangements for pregnant or parenting youth to learn parenting skills and promote long-term economic stability. Pregnant or parenting youth in maternity group homes are required to learn parenting skills, family budgeting, and health and nutrition to promote long-term economic independence and ensure the well-being of their children. Limited extension of 540-day shelter eligibility period for youth under 18 years old in the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act program. Youth can remain in the program until their 18th birthday or 180 days after the end of the 540-day period if qualified. Coordination assurances for Part A plan. SEC. 109 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to involve McKinney-Vento school district liaisons in providing educational services to runaway and homeless youth. SEC. 110 addresses coordination agreements for Part B plans. SEC. 110 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to include coordination with McKinney-Vento school district liaisons for educational services. SEC. 111 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to develop a plan for proper referral of homeless youth to various services. SEC. 112 focuses on coordinating programs. SEC. 112 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to ensure coordination of programs and services for homeless youth by consulting the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. SEC. 113 clarifies grant authority for activities under this title. SEC. 114 makes a technical amendment relating to demonstration projects. SEC. 114 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act by removing the word "temporary" from section 344. SEC. 115 repeals an obsolete provision by striking section 345. SEC. 116 adjusts the age limit for homeless youth seeking shelter. SEC. 117 authorizes appropriations. SEC. 117 authorizes appropriations for the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act, specifying funding amounts for fiscal years 2004-2008 and adjusting the allocation percentages for parts A and B. SEC. 118 requires a report on strategies to end youth homelessness within 2 years. SEC. 119 calls for a study on housing services and strategies. SEC. 119 requires a study on housing services and strategies for youth exiting programs funded under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act. It aims to report on long-term housing outcomes, available services, placement strategies, and models to prevent future homelessness. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to restrict the use of funds for distributing sterile needles for illegal drug injection. The Missing Children's Assistance Act is also amended to update findings. The Congress finds that thousands of children are abducted each year, putting them in grave danger. Missing children are at risk of harm and exploitation, often requiring expanded search efforts by law enforcement at all levels. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children serves as a vital resource for coordinating efforts. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children serves as the national resource center and clearinghouse, partnering with various agencies to find missing children and prevent child victimization. It operates a network linking online with missing children clearinghouses in all 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Scotland Yard, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, and INTERPOL. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children collaborates with various agencies worldwide, including Scotland Yard, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, and INTERPOL, to share information and images of missing children with law enforcement globally. The Missing Children's Assistance Act is amended to authorize appropriations for the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children until 2008. This is part of a broader act reauthorizing programs for runaway and homeless youth.
